logistics_movement.description: Terms for circus travel and setup operations

jump.example: The jump to Bakersfield was over two hundred miles.

haul.definition: The move from circus train to show lot
haul.example: The haul took three hours in the morning heat.

spotted.example: The boss hostler spotted the cookhouse wagon first.

dukey_run.example: It was a dukey run from the sleeper cars to the cookhouse.

one_day_stand.definition: A town where circus plays for single day
one_day_stand.example: Fresno was just a one day stand.

wildcatting.definition: Suddenly changing planned route to play unplanned towns
wildcatting.example: The polio scare had them wildcatting through the valley.

date.definition: A show's engagement in a town
date.example: The Bakersfield date was always a good one.

gas.definition: Trucks and tractors (originally contemptuous, accepted by 1954)
gas.example: The gas had replaced horses entirely by then.
gas.historical_note: Term of contempt in 1920s, accepted by late 1930s

spatial_geography.description: Terms for locations within the circus grounds

back_yard.definition: Off-limits area containing dressing rooms, padrooms, wardrobe, doctor's wagon
back_yard.example: Tommy wasn't allowed in the back yard yet.

padroom.definition: Ring stock tent where performing horses are kept
padroom.example: Jenny checked on her horse in the padroom.

clown_alley.definition: Area just outside back door of big top for clown props
clown_alley.example: The clowns waited in clown alley for their cue.

the_wagon.definition: The circus office wagon (also called Red Wagon)
the_wagon.example: Pay was handled at the wagon every Saturday.

big_top.example: The big top could seat three thousand.

blues.example: The towners packed the blues for the matinee.

star_bucks.definition: Reserved grandstand seats with folding backs, stenciled with star
star_bucks.example: The star bucks were already sold out.

quarter_poles.definition: Intermediate poles between side poles and center poles
quarter_poles.example: Rafael checked each quarter pole before the show.

ring_curbs.definition: The wooden rings defining performance area (42-foot diameter)
ring_curbs.example: The liberty horses circled inside the ring curbs.

personnel_titles.description: Job titles and roles within circus hierarchy

equestrian_director.definition: Man in charge of performance, blows whistle for act changes
equestrian_director.example: The equestrian director's whistle cut through the noise.
equestrian_director.note: NOT ring master on large shows - ring master only on small one-ring shows

boss_hostler.definition: Man in charge of all baggage/work horses, positions all wagons
boss_hostler.example: The boss hostler was first on the lot, last to leave.

candy_butcher.definition: Concession salesman who sells on circus seats
candy_butcher.example: The candy butchers worked the blues during intermission.

bally_broad.definition: Woman who dances in spectacles, works aerial ballet
bally_broad.example: Jenny had started as a bally broad before her solo act.

kid_worker.definition: Man who hires local boys to work for passes
kid_worker.example: The kid worker had twenty boys hauling water.
kid_worker.note: Boys did NOT water elephants - that's a myth

trouper.definition: Person with at least one full season on a traveling show
trouper.example: After that season, Tommy was a real trouper.

first_of_may.definition: Rookie, new worker in their first season
first_of_may.example: The first-of-mays always made the same mistakes.

towner.definition: Local person, not with the circus
towner.example: The towners lined up before the gates opened.

native.example: The natives didn't understand circus ways.

trailer.definition: Person following show without being on payroll
trailer.example: During hard times, good men trailered waiting for openings.

performance_terms.description: Terms related to shows and acts

house.definition: The crowd inside the tent for a performance
house.example: The evening house was twice the size of the matinee.

mechanic.definition: Safety belt/harness worn during training or dangerous tricks
mechanic.example: Jenny practiced the new trick with a mechanic.

lunge_rope.definition: Safety rope held by person on ground, through pulley to performer
lunge_rope.example: Rafael held the lunge rope while she practiced.

liberty_horses.definition: Horses performing complex drills without reins
liberty_horses.example: The liberty horses moved as one at the trainer's command.

iron_jaw.definition: Aerial act where performer hangs by mouthpiece in teeth
iron_jaw.example: Her iron jaw act was the most dangerous on the show.

john_robinson.example: The storm warning meant they gave a John Robinson.
john_robinson.trigger: Bad weather, late arrival, long jump ahead

straw_house.definition: Overflow crowd sitting on straw in front of seats
straw_house.example: The Fourth of July was always a straw house.

sell_out.example: The sell out meant nothing to the candy butchers working the blues.
sell_out.note: Not same as 'turn away' - may still have empty spaces

after_show.example: The after show featured a wild west exhibition.

spec.example: The opening spec used every performer on the show.

sunday_school_show.definition: Clean circus with no crooked games or illicit activity
sunday_school_show.example: Wallace Brothers ran a Sunday school show.

fireball_outfit.definition: Crooked show that scams towns, making future shows impossible
fireball_outfit.example: A fireball outfit had burned the town the year before.

flea_bag.example: Bad weather had turned them into a flea bag by September.

fold.definition: Close before end of regular season

ace_note.example: He didn't have an ace note to his name.

take.example: The take from the evening house was twice the matinee.

privilege.example: He bought the privilege for the balloon stand.

shill.definition: Employee pretending to be customer to entice others
shill.example: The shills broke the crowd toward the ticket boxes.

the_x.definition: Exclusive right to sell specific item on grounds
the_x.example: He had the X on cotton candy for the whole midway.

nut.definition: Operating costs that must be covered before profit
nut.example: The nut for the Bakersfield date was four thousand.

rigging_equipment.description: Technical equipment terms (especially for Rafael's expertise)

spanish_web.definition: Aerial rope apparatus for spinning/climbing acts
spanish_web.example: Jenny's Spanish web act was the highlight of the show.

web.example: Rafael inspected every web before the show.

rigging.definition: All overhead apparatus, ropes, and mounting hardware
rigging.example: The rigging had to be checked twice daily.

block.example: The block needed greasing before the evening show.
